channel.title: Dynamic class references
channel.description:
OKAY SO I KNOW THIS WONT WORK BUT IM SHOWING YOU AS AN EXAMPLE: [code] String className = "Class1"; int classVersion = className.version; [/code]
Where number is a public int defined in Class1.
I want to use the String as a class reference. Is this even possible?

item.title: Dynamic class references
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Nader[H.I.M”]link=topic=383434.msg2884507#msg2884507 date=1248523661]
HAHAHAHAHAH[/quote]
FUCK OFFFFFFFFFFFF.

Read full topic

item.title: Dynamic class references
item.dc:creator: @Nader_H.I.M Nader[H.I.M]
item.description:
@Nader_H.I.M wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:5, topic:290065”][quote author=inertia link=topic=383434.msg2878629#msg2878629 date=1248198671]

Yes this is possible.

int classVersion = Class.forName(className).version;

Wow I actually even tried that before and it didn’t compile so I thought I was going in the wrong direction…

I’ll try the reflection method Jython_

[hr]

yupp it worked thanks very much
[/quote]

Your welcome Unhandled meant the same but he had a brain fart[/quote]
HAHAHAHAHAH

Read full topic

item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:2, topic:290065”]Yes this is possible.

int classVersion = Class.forName(className).version; [/quote]
Wow I actually even tried that before and it didn’t compile so I thought I was going in the wrong direction…

I’ll try the reflection method Jython_

[hr]

yupp it worked thanks very much

Read full topic

item.title: Dynamic class references
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

Yep, via reflection:

Class<?> clazz = Class.forName(className); int version = clazz.getField("version").getInt(null);

Note that version must be public and static.

Read full topic
